body: When the project was initially being open sourced from HP,  the memory leak was observed with T4  driver.  @arvind-narain  and I worked together to identify the root cause of the issue with the mxosrvr and fixed it. I don't recollect the memory leak was observed with T2 driver. @arvind-narain can comment on this too. It might be good to check if there is memory growth with T2 driver without these changes by running the same tests before merging this.
I was referring to the change to escape out the variables so that the script would contain the variables itself. My bad, I wasn't clear enough.

Agreed with previous comment. @ryzuo  perhaps you have already done this. But it would help resolve the concern  if you ran YCSB without your changes and see if there is similar memory growth or 0 growth as @selvaganesang is saying and attaching those logs too.   If you still do see issues only with your changes we can definitely come up with a recourse to hep you analyze the growth or else address them separately in a different JIRA.

I understand your concerns. Indeed there's no growing with T2 observed without these changes, but there's growing with MXOSRVR. However, like I said, I have mem tracing code, of course includes all these new changes, shows no leaking already (about 3 leaking before, fixed already in the latest commit). So my suspicious is, probably there's inappropriate calls of CLI(maybe some descriptor or statement is not close, or anything else, I have no idea, there's no reference for CLI calls...), and it might cause something in executor during the statements's execution time like @sandhyasun said. T2 rowsets functionality uses a group of CLI calls like MXOSRVR does, slightly different(so looks like T2 is growing faster, or maybe it's just because it's multi-threaded, and all "connections" resident in one single process on the same machine). That's the only way that I can think of now, if you have anyother way out of this, surely  that would be great.

[mem_N_stmt_logs.zip](https://github.com/apache/incubator-trafodion/files/348988/mem_N_stmt_logs.zip)

These are the mem trace log and a statement trace log files last time I ran. The only object has never been deleted is created in SQLMXDriver.cpp line 114 (each row for each thread), and that's for srvrGlobal, a global object should be living in entire connection life cycle, thus we can't and don't have place to release it. And as well as the COMMIT and ROLLBACK statement.
Previous Test Aborted. New Check Test Started: https://jenkins.esgyn.com/job/ExtraTest-PR-master/18/

I had used google memory profiler earlier. See http://goog-perftools.sourceforge.net/doc/heap_profiler.html .  With this tool, I was able to narrow down the memory leak outside of Trafodion SQL engine. This includes any client component that issues Trafodion SQL CLI calls.

You can also monitor the memory usage in trafodion SQL using get process statistics for pid ( pid is of the form node_id , pin)command after the application reached a steady state. In case of YCSB, the application can be assume to have reached the steady state after first interval of information is displayed. Trafodion SQL uses its own heap management to manage the memory within the SQL engine. Please see the manuals for description of output of get process statistics command.
Extra tests failed due to 2 reasons  executor/TEST022 - due to PR 564. hive/TEST018 needs investigation . So looking into it.
Very glad to see this enhancement. Looking forward to reviewing it!

The hive/TEST018 is not because of the globals issue.After any unload statement, if a select  statement from the target table immediately, hdfs seems to return an EAGAIN error. I have added a sleep after every UNLOAD for now. But this needs to be addressed separately in a new JIRA and our hdfs  selects will need a retry mechanism for certain errors like EAGAIN.
looks go to me, do  you want me to commit it?

Please do. I'll take on a commit real soon but can't today.

Thanks for the change RuoYu. Sorry couldn't look into this yesterday. 

Do please check on the API. SQLGetTypeInfo() - it can also return back all the types supported by database. Hence the additional where clause should be added based on a condition. 

Currently jdbc tests are failing since expected count of types is 35 and we get back 0.

Java.lang.AssertionError: Number of datatypes expected:<35> but was:<0>
    at org.junit.Assert.fail(Assert.java:88)
    at org.junit.Assert.failNotEquals(Assert.java:743)
    at org.junit.Assert.assertEquals(Assert.java:118)
    at org.junit.Assert.assertEquals(Assert.java:555)
    at TestCat.TestBasic16(TestCat.java:524)
Also do please adjust the count in this test. Thanks.
Amazing that such a simple change can make such a big difference. Very cool!
Looks good, committing the changes now, since they don't require much discussion and since the check test failures are unrelated (not in executor tests).
thanks Hans for valuable comments. I will submit a new version including all changes asap. Some comments, I need your help to clarify, I don't quite understand, I will add reply to those at above.
thanks Hans for merge this, yes, it is to fix the regression test failure, so should be merged asap. I trigger an extra tests to verify again. I did regression on my dev workstation and seems good.

I believe JDBC ( and may be ODBC too) parses the first word in the SQL command to determine if the SQL command produces the result set or not. So, you may want to check the 'with' command from trafci to confirm it it works from it. If not, please consider making the change in JDBC  to flag the 'with' command to the one that produces the result set

Changes look good.

There are multiple places where code remains within "__ignore" def
or with initials ('sss') or commented out code.
Will those be cleaned up before merge or they left in to be enabled
for some future work?

check tests have failed. Is this due to the issue that is being
discussed for a different pull request?

They will get cleaned up in a future cleanup work that's in the pipeline. Want to keep the comments in case these globals changes cause any issues in QA/stress testing- they will be easy to identify. The check tests are failing due to the JDBC issue being worked on separately.
Thanks for making the fix so quickly.

Maybe we should get @prashanth-vasudev to review this PR? I feel it is good, this will be very important, and we still need to support more Hbase versions, especially HBase 1.2. So it will be better that we can decide to merge this or point out problems still need to fix in this PR.

Can some committer help to give some positive/negative comments on this PR?
This is rather important since without getProcedures() support, integration with Kettle in some use case is blocking, users were waiting for this feature.
The short-circuit check at line 125 needs to be updated to check for one of the new tables.

Thanks for the quick change RouYu. Like Selva mentioned we could have gone with 91, 92, 93 for both jdbc and odbc. We do use the same in case of SQLColumns. Can be handled separately. Currently merging this change since it does fix the current issue.
Is this good to be merged now?
Are there any more review comments that I need to take care of?

Sure thing, I will handle this soon. I'll go through the driver to see if there's other place mixing the definitions (trafodion driver has been confusing the compile time and run time versioning for a long time, or we can just omit that if no one would like to use the trafodion's own odbc driver manager). Then we will have some thorough tests.
@svarnau the check is to check the last table created, that is store_orc, which still is the last table, so it seems we don't need to update that check.
@ryzuo  Does Trafodion have ts own driver manager? If so, how does ODBC application use it?

@selvaganesang Yes, there is, only Linux ODBC Driver. It provides 2 .so files: libtrafodbc_drvr64.so and libtrafodbc64.so, the first one is only the driver providing API functions, which needs a 3rd party DM like unixODBC. The second one without the _drvr suffix is the the one with a built-in DM in it. These 2 .so files shall not be used at the same time. It only "manages" its own driver, handles the data source configuration, mapping/loading the driver API functions, definitions, etc.
If users want their apps to use trafodion native DM, only -ltrafodion64 is needed to link the second .so file, and TRAFDSN will be the dsn configuration file it uses. Otherwise, with the first one, app needs to use 3rd party DM, -lodbc for unixODBC for instance, then the dsn configuration file shall be odbc.ini (prerequisite, odbcinst.ini shall be configured to locate trafodion dirver .so file).
Looked at the 4 sql .java files . Changes look good  . Think it's ready to merge .
@selvaganesang , that is a good point, I still not try trafci, will do that later. I will be on biz trip for few days, so will not progress on this for a short while. Will continue when come back.

In that case, it is needed to ensure that the DM libtrafodbc64.so does the mapping correctly. Looking at the code of this DM, it is not clear to me what was the need for shipping this DM instead of using the 3rd party open source DMs in unix. This DM seems to be specific to Trafodion driver alone. If we can't ascertain the need for this DM, it might be better to avoid using this DM because the ODBC application needs to be re-linked to use this DM
